title: Lesson 1: Greetings and Introductions
text:
In Kyrgyz culture, greetings are warm and respectful. When meeting someone, it’s common to shake hands and ask about their well-being. The standard greeting is “Салам!” (Hello!), while “Саламатсызбы?” is a polite way to ask 'How are you?'—especially when speaking to elders or strangers.

When introducing yourself, you can say: “Менин атым [Your Name].” (My name is [Your Name].)
grammar:
Present tense of 'to be' is usually omitted in Kyrgyz. Identity or state is expressed through noun phrases alone.

Мен студент. – I am a student.
Ал дарыгер. – He/She is a doctor.
Сиз мугалимсиз. – You are a teacher. (formal)
Биз Бишкектенбиз. – We are from Bishkek.
Алар жакшы адамдар. – They are good people.

title: Lesson 2: Numbers and Counting
text:
Numbers are vital for telling time, shopping, giving your age, and more. Kyrgyz uses a decimal system. Note that numbers from 11 to 19 are formed by saying the unit first, then 'он' (ten): e.g., 'бир он' = 11.

Age is expressed with the verb 'жашта': “Мен жети жаштамын.” (I am seven years old.)
grammar:
Numbers + Nouns: The noun following a number stays in the singular form and does not take a plural suffix.

Эки китеп – two books
Беш дос – five friends
Он беш алма – fifteen apples
Жүз машина – one hundred cars
Миң адам – one thousand people

title: Lesson 3: Family Members
text: Family ties are central in Kyrgyz society. Extended families often live together or nearby. Respect for elders is shown through specific terms and polite speech. When talking about your family, you’ll use possessive suffixes to indicate 'my', 'your', etc.
grammar:
Possessive suffixes are attached to nouns to show ownership. The form changes based on person and vowel harmony.

Менин атам – my father
Сенин энең – your mother (informal)
Анын агасы – his/her older brother
Биздин үй-бүлөбүз – our family
Силердин туугандарыңар – your relatives (plural/formal)

title: Lesson 4: Personal Pronouns and Basic Sentences
text:
Pronouns help identify who is doing or experiencing something in a sentence. Kyrgyz distinguishes between formal and informal 'you', and plural forms are used respectfully even when addressing one person.

Use 'Сиз' (formal you) with elders, strangers, or in professional settings. Use 'Сен' only with close friends or children.
grammar:
Subject pronouns + predicates: Verbs and nouns directly follow the subject without a linking verb.

Мен окуйм. – I study.
Сен жазасың. – You write.
Ал келди. – He/She came.
Биз сүйлөшөбүз. – We talk.
Сиздер кайда жашайсыз? – Where do you live? (formal plural)

title: Lesson 5: Plural Nouns and Vowel Harmony
text: Kyrgyz plurals follow strict vowel harmony rules. The suffix changes depending on whether the word contains front vowels (е, и, ө, ү) or back vowels (а, ы, о, у). This ensures smooth pronunciation and is a key feature of Turkic languages.
grammar:
Plural suffixes:

  • Back vowels → -дар / -дор: бала → балдар, жол → жолдор
  • Front vowels → -дер / -дөр: көл → көлдөр, эне → энелер
  • Some words use -тар / -тер if ending in a voiceless consonant: китеп → китептер
Мен китептерди окуп жатам. – I am reading books.
Алар үйлөрдү сатышат. – They are selling houses.

title: Lesson 6: Daily Routines
text: Daily routines are expressed using verbs in the present tense. In Kyrgyz, the present continuous ('I am doing') and simple present ('I do') often use the same form with context or time words to clarify meaning. Common time expressions include 'эртең' (morning), 'түштөн кийин' (afternoon), and 'кечинде' (evening).
vocab: I get up in the morning.
grammar:
Present tense verb formation: Add personal suffixes to the verb stem. The stem often ends in a vowel.

Оку- + -йм → Мен окуйм. (I study.)
Иштө- + -сүз → Сиз иштейсиз. (You work. – formal)
Жаз- + -асың → Сен жазасың. (You write. – informal)
Ал тамактанат. – He/She is eating.
Биз азыр уйкуга жатабыз. – We are going to bed now.
